description: Part 1 of Flashcards Set 2 (Policy provisions, group & health insurance basics)

questions.question: What is a grace period in life insurance?
options: A period during which premiums can be paid late without forfeiting the policy
A period of free coverage after death
A period before the policy becomes effective
A period to change the beneficiary
questions.explanation: A grace period allows the policyowner to pay an overdue premium within a specified time without losing coverage.

questions.question: Which provision allows an insured to reinstate a lapsed policy?
options: Reinstatement provision
Grace period provision
Non-forfeiture provision
Incontestable clause
questions.explanation: The reinstatement provision allows a policyowner to restore a lapsed policy by paying back premiums and interest.

questions.question: What is the incontestable clause?
options: A clause that prevents the insurer from testing policy values
A clause that prevents the insurer from contesting the validity of the policy after a specified period
A clause that prevents the policyowner from changing beneficiaries
A clause that prevents claims from being paid
questions.explanation: The incontestable clause prevents the insurer from denying claims after the policy has been in force for a specified period (typically 2 years).

questions.question: What is the suicide clause designed to do?
options: Prevent all suicide claims from being paid
Limit the insurer's liability for death by suicide during the first few years of the policy
Require the beneficiary to prove cause of death
Allow the insurer to investigate beneficiary motives
questions.explanation: The suicide clause limits the insurer's liability for suicide deaths during the first 2 years of the policy.

questions.question: Which policy provision allows the policyowner to receive dividends?
options: Dividend provision
Non-participating provision
Participation provision
Profit-sharing clause
questions.explanation: The dividend provision allows policyowners to receive a portion of the insurer's surplus profits.

questions.question: What is a policy loan?
options: A loan taken by the insurer against the policy
A loan that the policyowner can take against the policy's cash value
A loan to pay premiums
A loan from the insurance company to the beneficiary
questions.explanation: A policy loan allows the policyowner to borrow against the accumulated cash value of the policy.

questions.question: What does a non-forfeiture provision provide?
options: Protection against loss of benefits due to non-payment
Protection for beneficiaries only
A guarantee of policy renewal
An option to increase coverage
questions.explanation: Non-forfeiture provisions provide values such as cash surrender, paid-up insurance, or extended term if premiums lapse.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a non-forfeiture option?
options: Cash surrender value
Paid-up insurance
Extended term insurance
Death benefit increase
questions.explanation: The three non-forfeiture options are cash surrender, paid-up insurance, and extended term insurance.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the free-look period?
options: To allow the insurer to review the application
To allow the policyowner to review the policy and return it if unsatisfied for a full refund
To delay premium payments
To extend the contestable period
questions.explanation: The free-look period (typically 10-30 days) allows the policyowner to cancel the policy and receive a full refund if unsatisfied.

questions.question: What type of group plan requires the employer to pay the entire cost?
options: Contributory plan
Noncontributory plan
Voluntary plan
Split-funded plan
questions.explanation: In a noncontributory group plan, the employer pays 100% of the insurance cost.

questions.question: In a group health insurance plan, what is the waiting period?
options: The period before any benefits are paid
The period an employee must work before becoming eligible for coverage
The period between claims
The period to cancel the policy
questions.explanation: A waiting period is the time an employee must be employed before becoming eligible for group health insurance coverage.

questions.question: What is COBRA?
options: A type of health insurance plan
A law requiring employers to offer continued health coverage to employees after separation
A benefit provided by all employers
A government health insurance program
questions.explanation: COBRA (Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act) requires group health plans to offer continuation coverage after employment ends.

questions.question: What is coordination of benefits in group health insurance?
options: Paying benefits from multiple policies to avoid overpayment
Combining benefits from different insurers
A method to determine which policy pays first
All of the above
questions.explanation: Coordination of benefits ensures that when an employee has multiple policies, payments don't exceed actual expenses.

questions.question: What is a pre-existing condition exclusion?
options: A period during which conditions existing before coverage began are not covered
A permanent exclusion from all coverage
An exclusion that applies only to the primary insured
A condition that can never be covered
questions.explanation: A pre-existing condition exclusion limits or delays coverage for conditions that existed before the policy effective date.

questions.question: What is an HMO (Health Maintenance Organization)?
options: A type of life insurance
A managed care health plan emphasizing preventive care and using network providers
A dental insurance plan
A government health program
questions.explanation: An HMO is a managed health care plan where members must use network providers and obtain referrals for specialists.

questions.question: What is a PPO (Preferred Provider Organization)?
options: A type of life insurance
A health plan that offers incentives to use network providers but allows out-of-network care
A dental only plan
A short-term insurance product
questions.explanation: A PPO is a health plan offering flexibility to use both in-network providers (at lower cost) and out-of-network providers.

questions.question: What is a deductible in health insurance?
options: A monthly premium payment
The amount the insured must pay out-of-pocket before coverage begins
The maximum the insurer will pay
A co-payment amount
questions.explanation: A deductible is the amount of covered expenses the insured must pay before the insurance coverage begins.

questions.question: What is a co-payment (copay)?
options: A shared cost between employer and employee
A fixed amount paid by the insured at the time of service
An annual premium
A percentage of total medical costs
questions.explanation: A copay is a fixed dollar amount the insured pays for specific services (e.g., $20 per doctor visit).

questions.question: What is coinsurance?
options: Coverage shared between two insurers
A percentage of costs shared between the insured and insurer after the deductible
A type of group coverage
An optional rider on policies
questions.explanation: Coinsurance is a cost-sharing arrangement where the insured pays a percentage (e.g., 20%) and the insurer pays the rest (e.g., 80%).

questions.question: What is an out-of-pocket maximum?
options: The maximum monthly premium
The total amount the insured must pay before the insurer covers 100% of costs
The annual deductible amount
A limit on emergency room visits
questions.explanation: An out-of-pocket maximum is the maximum amount the insured must pay in deductibles, copays, and coinsurance before the plan covers 100% of covered services.
